repnme.cdata!: West Bank and Gaza - Gaza Industrial Estate Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Gaza Industrial Estate Project
            development objectives are to increase direct and indirect
            employment in Gaza and contribute to Gaza's GDP by
            creating conditions conducive to private sector industrial
            investment, including appropiate physical infrastructure.
            The project has four components: 1) Off-site infrastructure,
            the construction of facilities to enable Palestinian
            utilities and agencies to provide necessary services to the
            GEI, including water, wastewater, sewage and stormwater
            disposal, electric power and access roads. 2) The land
            component will comprise leasing of land used for the site
            and for the installation of off-site infrastructure. 3) Site
            development, includes development of the GIE site,
            containing standard factory buildings, open lots,
            administration buildings and on-site distribution of
            infrastructure services. 4) Technical assistance component,
            includes institution building and project management for the
            Palestinian Industrial and Free Zones Authority (PIFZA),
            adquisition of environmental monitoring equipment for PIFZA
            and the Ministry of Industry, and training for staff of the
            Palestinian Environment Authority (PEnA).

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Gaza Industrial Estate
            Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment of the
            Gaza Industrial Estate Project, which will develop an
            industrial park to promote labor-intensive industries,
            posits negative environmental consequences and explores the
            following options for their mitigations. Adequately
            collecting stormwater and monitoring groundwater quality
            will mitigate ponding, soil erosion, and water
            contamination. Debris from vehicles will be taken to a
            disposal site or a trench-to-truck construction method will
            be adopted. Adopting specific archaeological mitigation and
            monitoring plans will prevent site destruction. To maintain
            the water supply, treated wastewater will be reused, water
            from Mekorot will be purchased, conservation will be
            encouraged, technologies will be implemented, and other
            water resources will be considered. Wastewater treatment
            provides for screening, equalization, biological treatment,
            post-equalization, tertiary filtration, and chlorinating
            treated effluents. Treated effluent and stormwater runoff
            will be stored and reused as irrigation water; and will
            require an extensive underground monitoring system to
            prevent industrial pollutants and increased salinization.
            Water logging and soil salinization, water-borne diseases,
            and agricultural pests will be offset by lining the
            immediate area of treated wastewater application. Solid
            waste not recycled or composted will be transferred to a
            plastic-lined landfill equipped with a leachate collection system.
